name: Madagascar Boa
description: It has camouflaged coloration to blend with fallen leaves on the ground or flickering shadows in trees. It comes in two color forms—one olive-brown, the other more orange. Like all boas, it has a triangular head, distinct neck, and robust body.
food_note: Vertebrates, mainly smaller mammals and birds
image_alt: Madagascar boa, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 1.3–2.2 m; tail 12% of length; weight 2–3 kg
attractions: The boa family (Boidae) consists of non-venomous snakes with vertical slit pupils, some—like the anaconda—reaching lengths of nine meters. The Madagascar boa, however, is among the smaller species. It hunts in tree canopies but mostly stays on the ground, active at night, locating prey with heat-sensitive receptors along its jaws. It coils around captured animals, stopping blood flow to the brain.
breeding: We have kept Madagascar boas at the zoo since 1997.
